Absolutely, striking a balance between states' rights and federal involvement is crucial to uphold equity and provide consistent access to essential services for all citizens. While states' autonomy can drive innovation and tailored solutions, federal oversight plays a critical role in setting minimum standards and addressing disparities that may arise. This cooperative approach ensures that no individual or community is left behind and that the overall well-being of the nation is upheld. However, I believe that bioethics plays an essential role in research. It's not about obstructing progress, but about maintaining our moral integrity. Bioethics helps us align our scientific pursuits with our core human values, ensuring we conduct research that honors these values. It's not a hindrance, but a guide towards responsible science.

I believe that prioritizing human rights globally may not always lead to a better future for all. In some cases, prioritizing human rights above all else can lead to interference in the internal affairs of sovereign nations, causing political instability and conflict. This interference can sometimes do more harm than good, disrupting delicate balances and exacerbating existing tensions. It's essential to consider the complexities of each situation and the potential unintended consequences of imposing a one-size-fits-all approach to human rights worldwide.

Charlie, thanks. Thank you all very much. Its been enjoyable. The great contest for the presidency is about the future, who can lead, who can get things done. Weve been through a lot together as a country — been through a recession, corporate scandals, war. And yet think about where we are; Added 1. 9 million new jobs over the past 13 months. The farm income in America is high. Small businesses are flourishing. Homeownership rate is at an all- time high in America. Were on the move. Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going; keep the taxes low, dont increase the scope of the federal government, keep regulations down, legal reform, a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals, and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy. And abroad, were at war. And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined. I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until were safe. The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe. There is more work to be done. Well stay on the hunt on Al Qaida. Well deny sanctuary to these terrorists. Well make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. Its the great nexus. The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction. But our long- term security depends on our deep faith in liberty. And well continue to promote freedom around the world. Freedom is on the march. Tomorrow, Afghanistan will be voting for a president.
